title: Mystery lotto player pockets $2.5 million prize as state's winning run continues
text:
T﻿he multimillion-dollar lottery prize-winning run in Tasmania continued on the weekend, with one mystery player pocketing $2.5 million.

Lottery officials are today urging residents and visitors in the city of Launceston to check their TattsLotto tickets to see if they're the lucky winner.

They say the holder of the winning ticket is probably starting their working week with no idea they are now an instant millionaire.﻿

The search is on for a mystery Tasmanian lotto player who pocketed $2.5 million on the weekend.. (Supplied)

The Tasmanian winner held one of the eight division one winning entries in draw 4605 on Saturday, September 6. Every winning entry was worth $2.5 million.

So far this year, the Apple State has recorded 11 division one wins, collectively worth more than $13 million. Five of the winning tickets have been in Launceston.

The latest winning entry was purchased at Racecourse Newsagency & Gifts in the Launceston Shopping Centre.

The Lott spokesperson Matt Hart says when the mystery discovers their new-found riches they'll be "jumping for joy".

"If you do discover that you are holding the winning ticket, contact The Lott on 131 868 to begin the process of claiming your prize," he said.

"This is a great reminder to all players to register their lottery tickets to a player card or online account with The Lott Members Club, so if you score a major prize, we can call you right away."

The winning numbers in TattsLotto draw 4605 last Saturday were 43, 6, 21, 10, 42 and 16, while the supplementary numbers were 23 and 36.

title: 'Miracle no one was hit': Car smashes through alterations shop
text:
A car has gone crashing into an alterations shop in Adelaide, with witnesses hailing it a "miracle" that no one was injured.

Emergency crews were called to George Street in Norwood about 11.30am today.

CCTV captured the silver Toyota making a U-turn and swiping three cars before driving onto a footpath on the opposite side of the road.

A car has come crashing into an alterations shop in Adelaide, with witnesses hailing it a "miracle" that no one was injured. (Supplied)

The car was seen knocking over a street sign and narrowly avoiding two women before it crashed into the alterations shop.

"Very loud, very loud," witness Sue Duong said.

Witnesses rushed to help the driver, a 46-year-old man from Kent Town, and called for help.

Firefighters worked to free the man, and the car was later towed away. ﻿

The driver was treated at the scene for minor injuries and fined for the crash.

The shop owner told 9News he was inside at the time, but was luckily in the back corner of the store﻿.

"It's ﻿a miracle no one was hit," Duong said.

title: NFL quick hits: Spitting issues continue, Rodgers rolls back the years
text:
The NFL is back with a jam-packed week one slate of games over in the USA.

Week one is, of course, far too early to get a read on how the rest of the season will pan out, but that's not going to stop people reading into just about anything and everything that the first suite of games has served up.

Whether it's a legendary star putting the boot into a former team, or a recent transfer proving his worth, here's what went down in week one of the NFL.

1. Rodgers rolls back years in comeback win on Steelers debut

Aaron Rodgers got off to a winning start with the Steelers. (AP Photo: Vera Nieuwenhuis)

Aaron Rodgers turned back the clock with a vintage performance in his Steelers debut that featured big throws, no turnovers and a late victory over his former team.

Rodgers threw four touchdown passes — two in a 50-second span in the second half — and Chris Boswell kicked a go-ahead 60-yard field goal with 1:03 remaining to lead Pittsburgh to a 34-32 victory over the New York Jets on Sunday.

"I love beating everybody," Rodgers, who finished 22 of 30 for 244 yards and the four scores, said.

"It doesn't matter who it is."

But this one had to be a little more satisfying, especially after he was released by the Jets and new coach Aaron Glenn in the off-season.

"I was happy to beat everybody associated with the Jets," Rodgers said when asked if he was pleased to beat Glenn.

"I gave as much as I could to the team. I didn't have any hard feelings about it not working out. I didn't maybe appreciate the way it went down in the end, but that's in the past.

"And we're one and zero."

2. Spitting epidemic continues in college football

Brendan Bett (90), in less controversial circumstances, transfered to Florida from Baylor this season. (AP Photo: Alan Youngblood)

It's not been a great week for players spitting at each other in American football.

Just two days after Philadelphia Eagles defensive tackle Jalen Carter was ejected for spitting on Dallas quarterback Dak Prescott in the NFL opener, Florida defensive lineman Brendan Bett was ejected for spitting at a South Florida player late in the Gators' 18-16 upset loss on Saturday night.

Bett, who transferred to Florida after two years at Baylor, was flagged for unsportsmanlike conduct, kicked out of the game and escorted to the locker room after spitting in the face mask of Bulls offensive lineman Cole Skinner.

It was one of two penalties assessed against the Gators on the final, 87-yard drive that set up Nico Gramatica's 20-yard field goal on the final play.

"We'll take a good look at it, but it's unacceptable," Florida coach Billy Napier said.

"I think we've got a lot of players in that room as well that have the same belief that it's unacceptable.

"When a guy does something like that, he's compromising the team. He's putting himself before the team. Everything the game is about, you're compromising. So there will be lessons to be learned there. Yeah, it's that simple."

3. Parsons gets sack on Packers debut

Former Cowboy Micah Parsons had a good start to life in the north. (AP Photo: Mike Roemer)

By acquiring defensive star Micah Parsons from the Dallas Cowboys in a pre-season trade just a week before the start of the season, Green Bay rocketed into contention for the Super Bowl before a snap had been taken.

His first start for the Packers featured a sack and an impressive all-round display against two-time defending NFC North champions Detroit and gave those pundits even more pause for thought.

The Lions, who scored an NFL-high 33.2 points per game last season, didn't reach the end zone until the final minute of the game as the Packers won 27-13.

Jordan Love threw a pair of touchdown passes as the Packers got points on their opening three possessions at Lambeau Field, a place where the Lions had won their last seasons.

From there, it was Parsons and the defence though, with the former Cowboy edge rusher getting a huge ovation from the Lambeau Field crowd when he was introduced before the game.

He got his first sack as a Packer with just over 4 minutes left in the game and applied pressure that led to Evan Williams's second-quarter interception, thwarting a Lions scoring opportunity.

Love went 16 of 22 for 188 yards with touchdown passes of 15 yards to Tucker Kraft and 17 yards to Jayden Reed. Josh Jacobs added a three-yard score in the fourth quarter, giving him a touchdown in a franchise-record nine straight games.

The Packers went 1-5 in divisional games last year, but won their 13th consecutive home opener, giving them the longest such streak since the Miami Dolphins also won 13 straight from 1976-88.

4. Lightning delays the inevitable

Bryce Young (right) had a disappointing performance. (AP Photo: Phelan M. Ebenhack)

The game between Carolina and Jacksonville was delayed roughly 75 minutes because of severe weather and lightning in the area.

Panthers quarterback Bryce Young might have hoped the delay was even longer.

The 24-year-old turned over the ball three times in the game, including throwing two interceptions, as the Jaguars won 26-10.

Young completed 18 of 35 passes for 154 yards.

The Jaguars were leading 10-3 when, with 8:32 remaining in the second quarter, players and coaches headed to locker rooms.

Fans in open areas were asked to move to "protected areas" as a thunderstorm storm hovered north-east of EverBank Stadium in Florida.

5. Kicking horror shows

Andre Szmyt (left) did not have a great day from the place kicking tee. (AP Photo: Sue Ogrocki)

Kickers don't tend to get much of the spotlight in the NFL — unless they're doing things wrong.

And boy did a couple of place kickers mess up this week.

Browns kicker Andre Szmyt missed an extra point and a 36-yard field goal in the second half as Cleveland lost their opener 17-16 to Cincinnati.

"What you've got to remember is that we've all been in a situation where we've all made mistakes before that have been a big part of costing us a football game. You got to shake it. It's not just on you. It's a team sport," quarterback Joe Flacco said about Szmyt's missed kicks.

"We're all going to be in there and rally together. Nobody wants to be in that situation and not come up for your team. But we've all been there and can understand not doing it."

Falcons kicker Younghoe Koo also struggled as his Atlanta side fell to a 23-20 defeat against the Buccaneers.

Koo, from South Korea, missed nine of his 31 kicks in 2024 and again fell short with a 44-yard field goal attempt that wasn't even close with 2 seconds remaining in the game.

"We've got to make those kicks," coach Rahaeem Morris said.

"Those are very makeable kicks. We've got to lock in and get that done."

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

Koo didn't hang around to address the media after the game. His locker was already cleared out by the time reporters and camera crews were allowed in.

It was left to his teammates to defend their kicker.

"We still trust him," said quarterback Michael Penix Jr, who directed a last-minute drive that put the Falcons in position to force overtime. "We still believe in him."

That being said, Tampa Bay's kicker Chase McLaughlin also had a tough day, missing from 44 yards in the third quarter and then hitting the upright with an extra point attempt in the final minute of the game.

"I'm not going to cuss here at the podium," coach Todd Bowles said.

"But I was pissed, to say the least."

All's well that ends well, I guess.

Week one NFL results

Thursday

Philadelphia Eagles 24-20 Dallas Cowboys

Friday

Los Angeles Chargers 24-21 Kansas City Chiefs

Sunday

Atlanta Falcons 20-23 Tampa Bay Buccaneers

Cleveland Browns 16-17 Cincinnati Bengals

Indianapolis Colts 33-8 Miami Dolphins

Jacksonville Jaguars 26-10 Carolina Panthers

New England Patriots 13-20 Las Vegas Raiders

Washington Commanders 21-6 New York Giants

New York Jets 32-34 Pittsburgh Steelers

New Orleans Saints 13-20 Arizona Cardinals

Seattle Seahawks 13-17 San Francisco 49ers

Denver Broncos 20-12 Tennessee Titans

Los Angeles Rams 14-9 Houston Texans

Green Bay Packers 27-13 Detroit Lions

Monday

Chicago Bears vs Minnesota Vikings

title: Turmoil in powerful nurses union as members vote on Victorian branch boss
text:
Members of the largest and most powerful union in Australia are voting for a new Victorian boss for the first time since 1989.

Three candidates have nominated for the Australian Nursing and Midwifery Federation (ANMF) Victorian branch secretary role after long-time secretary Lisa Fitzpatrick stepped down in July.

Ms Fitzpatrick resigned after a member stoush over a pay deal for its 111,000 Victorian members.

The three-way contest for the top job, which boasts a salary of $320,000, will be decided by postal ballot which opens today.

The ANMF is the largest and most powerful union in the country with about 331,000 members Australia-wide, and is one of the few unions with continually increasing membership.

Lisa Fitzpatrick campaigned to stop unqualified health assistants replacing nurses and midwives in 2011. (Supplied: Australian Nursing and Midwifery Foundation)

The last Victorian nurses' union election was won by Belinda Morieson in 1989 after she defeated Irene Bolger who was sacked as the Australian Nursing Federation Victorian secretary and failed to win back her old job.

Former long-time ANMF secretary Ms Fitzpatrick resigned on July 4 after almost 24 years in the role.

Assistant secretary Maddy Harradence was appointed to replace her.

Ms Harradence is running for the top job, along with former union organiser Quinn McGuinness.

Jimmy Parel, who is trying to start an new nurses' union, is also running.

The union says it's proud of the fight put up by members to secure better pay and conditions. (ABC News: Lucas Hill)

Lawyers called in

The election is shrouded in controversy.

Ms Harradence emailed members on August 19 and 21 notifying them an investigation had commenced into "unauthorised use of members' information".

"The branch … is in communication with our IT specialists, the Australian Electoral Commission and our lawyers," the email from Ms Harradence said.

The email sent to ANMF members alleged "unauthorised use of member information" during the union's election. (Supplied)

The allegation has now been removed from ANMF's website.

The contested election comes after a shake-up in the Victorian division of the Community and Public Sector Union (CPSU), when members this year dumped secretary Karen Batt, who had been in the role since Jeff Kennett was Victorian premier in 1993.

Former secretary resigns

In 2024, Victorian ANMF members shocked union leaders by publicly rejecting an in-principle pay deal struck by Ms Fitzpatrick.

At a Melbourne meeting of members in May last year ANMF members voted down the proposed pay deal, and in the aftermath members called for Ms Fitzpatrick to resign.

The failed pay proposal included wage increases of between 18 and 23 per cent over four years, but there was also a promise of additional pay rises contingent on the outcome of a Fair Work Commission wage case.

About a month later, union members ended industrial action when a 28.4 per cent pay rise over four years was approved.

Ms Fitzpatrick stepped down as secretary on July 4 and Ms Harradence was appointed to the role, which is allowed under union rules.

Madeleine Harradence, pictured at a rally in Bendigo, is running in the election. (ABC News: Tyrone Dalton)

Incumbent defends record

Ms Harradence was first elected to the union's state branch council in 2013, and has worked in the Loddon-Mallee and Mildura regions.

If elected she wants to address violence against nurses, increase wages plus improve nurse-staff-to-patient ratios.

"It's a transitional period and it probably makes some people go 'Well, time for change' ... I respect the democratic process," she said.

"We absolutely acknowledged [the pay deal] was voted down, and we all went back to the negotiating table, and we got clarity."

Nurse-to-patient ratios are a key issue for the union. (ABC News: Keane Bourke)

Fight for better conditions

Contender Mr McGuinness is an emergency department nurse.

He said the union had lost its way and needs to lobby harder to get mandated nurse-to-patient ratios in mental health and private hospitals.

He questioned the union spending million of dollars on holiday accommodation for members.

According to the ANMF's 2023-24 annual report its property portfolio was worth $103.8 million which includes holiday units in Bright and Ocean Grove, its Melbourne head office and another property in North Melbourne.

However this figure is what the union paid for the properties, not what they are worth now, and its total assets were $119 million.

Quinn McGuinness is running for Victorian secretary as part of a group calling themselves the Member First Team. (Supplied)

"I'm all for members having an opportunity to have a holiday, but I'm less convinced the union should be subsidising it," he said.

"We've lost focus on some of the key reasons why our union exists … to get better pay and conditions for our members."

Mr McGuinness wants the union member helpline reinstated, something that was shut down over the COVID period.

"We're probably the only union in the country where you can't actually call the union and get phone advice," he said.

The third candidate, Mr Parel, is an emergency nurse at Melbourne's Northern Hospital.

Since 2021 he has been trying to register a new nurses' union called United Nurses of Australia with the Fair Work Commission, which has been opposed by the ANMF.

"There's nothing wrong with having another union because that makes things more transparent and more competition for members," he said.

Mr Parel said the union had failed to help enforce mandatory nurse-to-patient ratios at a Melbourne hospital, and he paid more than $5,000 to hire a lawyer to apply the law.

He also wanted to slash the branch secretary salary back to $80,000.

"I want to bring the [secretary] salary down to an average working nurse's salary," Mr Parel said.

The union postal ballot for all positions will run from September 8 until October 6.

title: Player 'with natural kick' switches from Aussie Rules to American football
text:
Police escorts to US college stadiums and booked-out hotels are the new normal for Jake Stoeckel.

The 22-year-old has moved from Renmark in South Australia's Riverland to Kent, Ohio for at least three years to play American football as a punter for the Kent State Golden Flashes.

Jake Stoeckel grew up in Renmark, in the South Australian Riverland region. (Supplied: Rachael Stoeckel)

August was a whirlwind of change for Stoeckel, who spent 25 hours travelling before arriving in Kent in the early hours of August 1.

"By 6:30am, I was at the practice facility ready to go, and was there until 9pm … pretty much did that for the first week straight before we had half a day off," he said.

" It's been quite an experience so far — I'm enjoying every minute of it. "

Taking the punt on American football

Stoeckel was well known in the Riverland sporting scene, notably in Australian Rules football for the Renmark Rovers, and tennis.

Jake Stoeckel was Renmark Rovers' U15 best and fairest and leading goal kicker with 31 goals in 2017. (Supplied: Rachael Stoeckel)

His interest in American football was piqued during work experience with the Essendon Football Club about two years ago.

"I was talking to [former Australian Rules footballer] Dustin Fletcher — both his boys are over here doing it and one of them is in Ohio as well," Stoeckel said.

"I spoke to him about it and then kind of came out and gave it a shot myself."

Stoeckel trained with Prokick Australia in Melbourne and said he had been "working towards coming to college from that moment".

Jake Stoeckel played his first game as a college football punter on August 30. (Supplied: Milan McMichael, Kent State Athletics)

According to the Melbourne Sports Law Association, Australians make up about 46 per cent of punters in college football teams.

There are five Australian-raised punters in the NFL currently — Mitch Wishnowsky, Michael Dickson, Tory Taylor, Cameron Johnston and Matthew Hayball.

Prokick owner and head coach Nathan Chapman said AFL skills were transferable and it was becoming more common for Australians to travel to the US for college football.

"We get so many more enquiries now because the [sporting] coverage is very good," he said.

"I think it's opened their eyes to know that it's a legitimate pathway, you can get educated from it and get a college degree paid for, and you can experience playing big-time football."

Mr Chapman said Stoeckel was a consistent player who had worked hard on his craft.

Nathan Chapman spent a pre- and off-season with the Green Bay Packers in 2004 before returning to Australia. (Supplied: Nathan Chapman)

"He has a really natural kick of the football [and] has some great skills," he said.

"He turned up to training, he did all his work … it was just a matter of time for him to get his opportunity.

"To watch to his first kick was pretty special."

Growing into a sports star

Stoeckel's first game for the Golden Flashes on August 30 resulted in a 21-17 win against Merrimack College.

It was the team's first win since 2023 after a 21-game losing streak.

Jake Stoeckel says the following college football has in the United States is insane. (Supplied: Milan McMichael, Kent State Athletics)

"That was my first time on the field … actually being out there and having some pretty big boys running at you is quite intimidating," Stoeckel said.

" A lot of them are like 6'5" [1.95 metres], 110kg and move faster than I ever could. "

Stream now on ABC iview Photo shows 5 women looking concerned in front of a beach with Family Next Door and iview logo. The enigmatic Isabelle arrives in the quiet seaside cul-de-sac of Pleasant Court — and suspicions quickly rise. Stream all episodes now on ABC iview.

The fanfare for college football was palpable during Stoeckel's trip to Dix Stadium before the game.

"We had a police escort to the stadium," he said.

"Just the scale of where you end up and how big it is across the country is insane."

His most recent game included a trip to Texas, where he said a hotel had been "completely booked out" for the team.

Jake and Rachael Stoeckel at the airport before Jake left for Kent, Ohio. (Supplied: Rachael Stoeckel)

Mum Rachael Stoeckel said she raised her two sons, Jake and Nate, to do something they were passionate about.

"Jake's always had above-average gross motor, even as a little person, and sport just was a really big focus for him," she said.

"He'd excel in whatever sport he was in, but American football was not something I thought he would end up doing.

" To see him out there, I'm the proudest mum in the Riverland at the minute. "

Jake Stoeckel grew up playing tennis and Australian football in the Riverland. (Supplied: Grant Schwartzkopff)

A piece of home

The family will fly to Ohio in the October school holidays to visit Stoeckel and watch him play.

Until then, Stoeckel has a little piece of home with him after the team added stickers of the Australian flag and the Renmark postcode to his helmet.

An Australian flag sticker has been added to Jake Stoeckel's Golden Flashes football helmet. (Supplied: Rachael Stoeckel)

"That was awesome, I didn't actually know they were doing that," he said.

"I've told Cliff our equipment guy I'm going to make sure he gets some Australian treats like some Tim Tams … so he's looking forward to it."

title: FOGO bin system on verge of collapse among early adopters
text:
As more Perth councils bring in a third bin for food waste, some of WA's earliest adopters of the so-called FOGO system are just months away from potentially scrapping the scheme.

A third bin for food and garden organic waste (FOGO) was rolled out in Bunbury, south of Perth, more than 10 years ago and most other South West councils followed suit.

It was lauded as a "radical" but effective solution to the state's waste woes — and the WA government vowed to introduce FOGO to all Perth and Peel councils by the end of 2025.

Many Perth councils have now also rolled out FOGO bins, including Victoria Park, which introduced them just weeks ago.

Meanwhile, in the birthplace of FOGO, the waste has been going to landfill for months after the Bunbury Harvey Regional Council stopped processing it due to contamination.

For more than a decade, locals in the South West have been using a third, FOGO bin (right). (ABC South West WA: Jacqueline Lynch)

South West councils have been scrambling to find another way to deal with the waste but a recent council tender process failed to find a solution.

Some local governments including the Shire of Collie, the Shire of Harvey and the Shire of Capel are actively considering scrapping the FOGO system.

When it was introduced, Bunbury was praised for its state-leading solution to waste. (ABC South West: Kate Stephens)

'It's not working'

Seven local South West councils are calling on the WA government to urgently intervene.

Shire of Dardanup President Tyrrell Gardiner said the ideal solution would be a local processing centre, a plan that could cost upwards of $10 million.

Tyrrell Gardiner says if there is no solution by Christmas, the council will look at scrapping the FOGO bin. (ABC South West: Jacqueline Lynch)

He said if the council could not find a solution by Christmas, the bins could be removed.

"We would be getting to 12 months of the FOGO not being handled as we had intended," he said.

"The time frame on hoping to get a FOGO solution is rapidly closing and if we don't get something soon, the third bin will be gone in its current format.

" We've tried it in a format, it's not working and we've got to find another solution or it will go. "

He said given the tip just outside of Dardanup had long been taking waste from Perth, he felt the government should help.

Dardanup tip takes waste from Perth and other areas in WA. (ABC South West WA: Jacqueline Lynch)

A state 'failure'

The issue has largely united South West local governments.

Shire of Capel's deputy president Sebastian Schiano said it was a disappointing situation.

“At a time when local governments are adopting local FOGO processing and FOGO collection it seems the South West is held with its hands and nowhere to go," he told the council.

" That is a state government failure, a failure to deliver viable waste solutions in the South West. "

There are calls for the WA government to invest in more processing facilities, including in the South West. (ABC South West WA: Jacqueline Lynch)

The WA government said it was committed to the three bin system.

"FOGO remains an important part of our communities' move towards a more circular waste economy [and] reducing the amount of waste going to landfill," Environment Minister Matthew Swinbourn said.

" We recognise that some councils have faced challenges and we have been working with them to find solutions. "

He said the state had offered some money to South West councils for transporting waste.

Make it work or walk away

Meanwhile, more and more Perth councils have taken up state government grants and brought in the system.

The City of Rockingham, which introduced the bins at the end of June, said the rollout was "progressing well" and the rubbish was successfully being processed by contractor Veolia.

In some Perth councils, like the City of Rockingham, FOGO has been "progressing well." (Suppied: City of Rockingham)

Others, including WA's largest council by population, have doubts.

City of Stirling Mayor Mark Irwin said council wanted to see the issues dealt with before spending millions rolling out the bins to 250,000 residents.

"We're not confident that those processing facilities are able to cater for the volume from the City of Stirling," he said.

Mark Irwin says the council is holding off on bringing in FOGO until it is confident the system works. (ABC News)

"To put it in perspective, the city's population is close to the whole of the Northern Territory so it will have significant implications for our waste streams across the state"





Steve Thomas says the state's trial of FOGO has "failed". (ABC South West WA: Jacqueline Lynch) South West Liberal member Steve Thomas said if the state government wanted to see the FOGO system work in Perth and the South West, it needed to "seriously invest".

"We have been a trial in the South West in terms of FOGO and you would have to say that that trial has failed," he said.

"If the state government wants to replicate that failure in the metropolitan area with great big volumes, good luck to them.

"What they need to do is either progress FOGO across the board and invest in it fully and make it work or walk away from it."

title: Queensland fans gear up for 'biggest ever' AFL game
text:
Elated Gold Coast Suns fans say the club is finally being rewarded after "15 years of struggle", as the team prepares for its first-ever semifinal match following a thrilling win against Fremantle.

The one-point win elimination final win over the Dockers at Perth Stadium on Saturday night kept the Glitter Strip's fans on the edge of their seats until the siren went off.

Dennis and Ingrid Dawes have been avid Gold Coast Suns fans since the club entered the league in 2009.

"It was magic, absolutely magic," Mrs Dawes said.

The fact that the winning point was kicked by the retiring David Swallow with just nine seconds left on the clock just added to the hype.

"Could not have scripted it any better — it was the footy gods being nice," Ms Dawes said.

Ingrid and Dennis Dawes are long-term Suns fans. (ABC Gold Coast: Dominic Cansdale)

And the fact that it will be played against Brisbane Lions in the state's first finals QClash makes it a massive moment for the code in Queensland.

Dennis Dawes said "everybody is chuffed" for this weekend's match against the Brisbane Lions, which will be "great for the code".

"Brisbane's banged up a bit so there's every chance," he said.

"Imagine them playing Collingwood in a couple weeks time — that would be just so good."

Harry Kerr (far right) and his team mates from Carrara Saints Football club celebrate "silly Sunday". (ABC Gold Coast: Dominic Cansdale)

Harry Kerr and his team mates from the Carrara Saints footy club have been celebrating the Suns' win most of the weekend, along with their own reserve division grand final win.

"We were actually at the pub with all the boys so it was pretty special," he said.

" Everyone was cheering it on — stuff you can't even write about. "

He said the Suns' 2025 season has changed "the vibe" around the club.

"Having juniors and young people seeing that happen, hopefully driving them to come and try the sport, it's massive for footy in Queensland," Mr Kerr said.

"Winning this years has helped — a lot of people are talking about them a lot more now and starting to take notice."

Stream now on ABC iview Photo shows 5 women looking concerned in front of a beach with Family Next Door and iview logo. The enigmatic Isabelle arrives in the quiet seaside cul-de-sac of Pleasant Court — and suspicions quickly rise. Stream all episodes now on ABC iview.

Queensland Premier David Crisafulli was also thrilled with the weekend's result and said he was looking forward to the QClash this weekend.

His electorate is in the Gold Coast and he is backing the Suns.

"It'll be good either way but you've got to love an underdog story, haven't you? Mr Crissafulli said.

"Go the Suns."

Suns arrive home

The Suns' players flew back into the Gold Coast on Sunday afternoon where they were greeted by jubilant fans.

Suns super fan Terry Vanes and his daughter Zara Vanes cheered on the players as they touched down at Coolangatta airport.

Mr Zanes joked that the win was "much better" than the birth of his daughter.

"[It's] momentous for our club — after 15 years of struggle, we're here on the big stage and we can match it," Mr Vanes said.

Terry and Zara Vanes are passionate Gold Coast Suns fans. (ABC Gold Coast: Dominic Cansdale)

He was riding the high of the win and had no concerns about facing the Lions this weekend.

"No contest, they're out, they're gone," he said.

"We are heading up the M1 for victory, we're bringing it back down the Gold Coast — look out Collingwood the following week."

Back on home soil, captain Noah Anderson said it did not feel real when the buzzer sounded on Saturday and he realised his team had taken home the win.

Noah Anderson (centre) addresses the Gold Coast Suns during their round 20 match. (Getty Images: AFL Photos/Russell Freeman)

"In our first final playing away in a hostile environment to be able to come out on top the way we did was pretty special," Anderson said.

The star midfielder said it was even more special that he was playing in front of a horde of Gold Coast supporters in the final moments of the game.

"They were so loud, it shows the growth of our club that we get such good representation away from home," he said.

History-making match

AFL Queensland chief executive Trisha Squires said next week's semifinal against Brisbane could be the biggest game in Queensland AFL history.

"This will be the biggest ever QClash," Ms Squires said.

"We have the two Queensland clubs in the AFL finals for the first time in the 129-year history of the AFL/VFL.

" It's a big moment for Queensland footy. "

Ms Squires said participation numbers would surge in Queensland because of the teams' successes.

"We've broken participation records the past three years in a row — at the moment, we're up 12 per cent on this time last year," Ms Squires said.

"We know the next couple of weeks is going to add to that because more people will start to get curious about our game and get involved in our game."

She said historically, Queensland had not been considered an AFL state, but it "really" had become one.

title: Pacific leaders to meet amid flurry of 'comical' gift giving
text:
This week, Pacific leaders — as well as hundreds of officials, diplomats and journalists — will gather in the capital of Solomon Islands, Honiara, for the region's most important political meeting.

It comes amid a flurry of gift-giving between China and Australia that has highlighted — on what one expert labelled an almost "comical" level — the tit-for-tat efforts by both countries to exert influence on the ground in Honiara ahead of the meeting.

Meanwhile, before the meeting, Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will on Tuesday wing his way to another Pacific Island nation — Vanuatu — where he is widely expected to sign a landmark new pact between the two countries.

And next week, Mr Albanese and a host of Pacific leaders will descend on Port Moresby to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Papua New Guinea's independence — a milestone that marks a tectonic moment in the Pacific's political history.

One of the dozens of vehicles handed over by China — and Australia — ahead of this week's Pacific Islands Forum meeting. (Supplied: Solomon Islands government)

The political pageantry and flurry of meetings will reveal quite a lot about where the region is heading, and the way it is shaping (and being shaped by) some of the massive strategic and economic disruptions reverberating around the globe.

Why Vanuatu first?

It is not surprising that Mr Albanese's first Pacific stop will be Vanuatu.

Last month, no fewer than three federal government ministers hiked up to the top of a spectacular volcano on the island of Tanna to give their "initial" agreement to a pact which they've promised will "transform" the relationship between Vanuatu and Australia.

Hot diplomacy: Senior ministers from Australia and Vanuatu initialled the Nakamal Agreement at the top of Mount Yasur, an active volcano. (ABC News: Lillyrose WelWel)

The "Nakamal Agreement" has emerged from the ashes of a contentious 2022 security pact between the two countries, which was signed by former prime minister Ishmael Kalsakau but effectively torched by the incumbent, Jotham Napat.

Australia is expected to funnel some $500 million to Vanuatu over a decade under the agreement, with money flowing into the Pacific nation's key development, climate and security priorities.

China has emerged as a major player in Vanuatu, and the federal government believes this agreement will also help it entrench Australia's position as the country's major security partner and head off Beijing's attempts to bed down its police training teams in the country.

Australia hasn't publicly said if Mr Albanese will officially sign the agreement while in the country, even though Mr Napat has repeatedly declared that the prime minister is coming to Vanuatu specifically to put pen to paper.

Half-a-billion-dollar pact between Australian and Vanuatu close to being signed Photo shows A woman and man shake hands standing in front of flags smiling at the camera The Nakamal Agreement will cover infrastructure, climate change resilience and economic development but questions remain about what security and travel arrangements will be agreed to.

Perhaps that is just because Vanuatu's politics are notoriously fluid and unpredictable, and nobody in Australia wants to celebrate signing an agreement until after it is sealed.

Another thing that is not yet perfectly clear is exactly what Australia gets in return for substantially ramping up assistance and investment.

The Pacific nations of Nauru and Tuvalu have both signed sweeping treaties with Australia that effectively give Canberra veto power over their national security decisions, but Vanuatu has a long history of non-alignment, and Mr Napat has insisted he won't give his imprimatur to anything similar.

Tuvalu is an island nation in the Pacific Ocean, lying about halfway between Hawaii and Australia. (Reuters: Kirsty Needham)

The Australian government isn't publicly contradicting the prime minister, but in private, it's suggesting that Vanuatu has, in fact, made concessions — hinting that Chinese policing teams in the country will be gradually wound down as a result of the pact.

But the full picture might only become clear well after the agreement is signed.

Absent friends, 'comical' police gifts

After the festivities in Vanuatu, Mr Albanese and Mr Napat will hop on the prime minister's RAAF plane and head to Solomon Islands for the Pacific Islands Forum (PIF) leaders meeting in Honiara.

They'll arrive at a meeting that has already generated plenty of controversy well before officially kicking off.

New Zealand, France, Fiji, Tuvalu, the US and Australia have all sharply criticised Solomon Islands' decision to block about two dozen "dialogue partner" nations from joining the meeting — with NZ's foreign minister even suggesting Honiara wouldn't have secured hosting rights if they'd known this was what it was planning.

Why is there a stoush over the Pacific's top meeting next month? Photo shows A group poses for a photo on chairs in front of a row of national flags. The Pacific's leaders are grappling with Solomon Islands’ contentious decision to block all outsiders from the region's most important annual meeting next month. So what does the episode say about how strategic competition is reshaping the region?

Solomon Islands insists it's only "deferring" the meeting with dialogue partners for procedural reasons, but few are buying that — with most Pacific officials convinced Solomon Islands Prime Minister Jeremiah Manele was forced into the contortion because he wanted to avoid a damaging stoush over Taiwan's participation in the meeting.

While PIF nations have (in some cases grudgingly) accepted the compromise, expect some PIF nations to push Pacific leaders to make it crystal clear that the saga should not be repeated in the future.

Partner nations excluded from the meeting will be watching closely to see if non-Pacific nations with diplomatic representatives in Honiara (including the UK, Japan, the US and — of course — China) manage to secure their own meetings with Pacific leaders on the meeting sidelines.

Kiribati's president Taneti Maamau arriving in Honiara over the weekend. (Supplied: PIF Secretariat)

Expect plenty of fireworks and controversy if any of these nations — particularly the United States or China — manage to elbow their way into the meeting.

There will also be a subterranean arm wrestle over exactly what role Chinese police teams in Solomon Islands play in providing security.

This is ground zero in Australia's broader struggle to stop Beijing from establishing itself as a legitimate security and policing player in the Pacific.

There's been a contest between the two nations on the ground in the lead-up to PIF, what one expert labelled as "comical", with both nations tripping over each other to hand over new vehicles and equipment to the Royal Solomon Islands Police Force.

The Chinese embassy in Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands. (Reuters: Charley Piringi)

This was beautifully illustrated in one double-page spread inside a Solomon Islands newspaper a couple of weeks ago, which contained almost identical headings besides the pictures of Chinese and Australian largesse.

All this might help explain why some Pacific leaders and civil society representatives — even those sceptical of China — are quietly relieved by Mr Manele's diktat, and hope the absence of some sharp-elbowed friends might make it easier for the meeting to focus on some of the issues at the heart of its future.

Climate crisis and the 'ocean of peace'

At the top of that list, as ever, lies climate change — and the Pacific's race to access the resources and funding it needs to try to adapt to the chaos it is already starting to bring.

Pacific leaders are expected to officially ratify and operationalise the Pacific Resilience Facility (PRF), a new fund regional leaders have set up to try to give Pacific island nations easier and quicker access to climate finance.

While several nations have already stumped up cash — including Australia, which is the PRF's largest donor so far with $100 million pledged — it's still well short of the $500 million it wants to get in the kitty.

But the very fact they've managed to get the PRF up and running will give heart to those gathered in Honiara.

Australia and Türkiye fighting over COP31 Photo shows A large auditorium with rows of chairs facing three PowerPoint screens Türkiye rejects Australia's bid to host the COP31 climate summit in Adelaide.

Pacific leaders will have another powerful weapon at their disposal: the International Court of Justice Advisory Opinion on climate change will help them press major polluters to move with much more urgency to cut emissions and help them respond to breakneck change.

The meeting is also shaping up to deliver another endorsement of Australia's bid to co-host the COP31 climate meeting with the Pacific next year, although time is running short thanks to a protracted struggle with Türkiye over who should secure the massive event.

The Pacific will hope that a circuit breaker might be looming — Prime Minister Anthony Albanese is due to sit down with Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan on the sidelines of the United Nations General Assembly.

Until Australia actually secures the bid, it's hard for leaders to have a detailed conversation about what the massive event — which is expected to draw some 50,000 people to Australia — might look like and exactly what role Pacific nations can play.

In the meantime, some Pacific nations are moving on with their own conservation agenda, including a plan to announce a vast New Melanesian Ocean Reserve — which will become one of the world's largest protected zones.

Australia and Vanuatu agree to pact worth $500m atop a volcano Photo shows A man holds a large wooden implement in front of another man who is smiling Senior ministers from both countries journeyed to the top of Mount Yasur to initial the Nakamal Agreement, but many details linked to the deal remain under wraps.

That's not the only looming oceanic declaration — the "Ocean of Peace" first championed by Fiji Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka will also be debated and, very likely, rubber-stamped by leaders during the meeting.

As ever, Australia has been trying to frame that declaration in terms that affirm Pacific solidarity (and exclude China) by stressing "Pacific-led" security solutions.

But it's likely the final declaration will be broad enough for all players to draw what they like from the text: an earlier draft of the Ocean of Peace declaration seen by the ABC calls on outside players to engage with the Pacific in a way that "supports national and Pacific-led approaches" — a formulation wide enough to drive a bus through.

Ironically, the exclusion of so many players from Honiara might fuel even closer scrutiny of what happens in Solomon Islands this week, with every dollar committed, every clause put on paper, and every word in every statement, watched very intently — from a distance.

title: The Australian woman who spearfished a 162.5kg striped marlin
text:
In the world of spearfishing, marlin sit at the extreme end of possible targets.

They are some of the biggest, fastest fish in the world.

Nikki Watt, 36, from Tweed Heads is one of the few people in Australia game to do it.

"It can be really intimidating," she says.

Nikki Watt with the world record 162.5-kilogram marlin in Eden, NSW. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

"You could easily get dragged down hundreds of metres, and you're never going to make it back up.

"But it's so amazing. It overshadows all the fear, to see a marlin lit up [with colour], hunting. It's an incredible experience."

In 2025 she fulfilled a dream, spearing a world-record 162.5-kilogram striped marlin.

But just three months prior to achieving this feat, she thought she might never dive again.

Hooked on marlin

Nikki grew up spearfishing in far north Queensland. As a young adult, she'd heard of people spearing billfish like marlin.

"At the time it just sounded outrageous and unbelievable," she says.

"When I started to learn it was achievable, I thought, well let's have a crack.

Nikki Watt, pictured with a nannygai off Port Lincoln, SA, doesn't just target large fish such as marlin. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

"I realised it wasn't the biggest or strongest person against a fish. It was more about strategy."

In 2016 she got her first taste of it in Exmouth, WA, and despite losing a large marlin on the trip, she was hooked.

The following year, Nikki speared a women's record black marlin, and by 2021 she had added a sailfish and blue marlin to the list, thus achieving one of the highest honours in spearfishing, the so-called "grand slam".

A striped marlin, if she speared one, would see her become the first woman in the world to accomplish the coveted Super Slam.

But despite multiple attempts, the striped marlin would elude her.

Nikki Watt's partner Bryson Sheehy is also an Australian spearfishing champion. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

A surprise diagnosis

In October 2024, two weeks before she was due to marry fellow "spearo" Bryson Sheehy, Nikki found a lump on her left breast.

She waited until after the wedding to get it tested, and in December got the news: she had breast cancer.

Nikki underwent a mastectomy the very next day.

"I didn't process it," she says.

"For a few weeks I woke up in disbelief and was still questioning whether it was real."

She started chemotherapy in the new year.

Nikki Watt recovering from her surgery in December 2024. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

Despite the surgery being a success, Nikki was uncertain about her long-term prognosis, and what it meant for her life ahead.

"There were thoughts of, 'Am I going to survive beyond a couple of years let alone do anything?'" she says.

" I never expected to dive again. "

However, Nikki's chemo soon stopped, as the cancer's progression was deemed low risk.

She had already started seeing a rehabilitation therapist, who helped her work out how she could load a speargun again.

"I had a moment where I broke down and said, 'I don't think I'll be able to load this gun,'" she says.

"And he said, 'Nikki, you don't need a pec major to load a speargun.'"

Nikki Watt's chemotherapy was cut short after successful surgery. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

Nikki Watt with her daughter Blair and a line-caught Kimberley barramundi. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

A record fish

March and April are the prime times for marlin fishing in NSW, where fish congregate off places like Jervis Bay, Bermagui and Eden.

Nikki, Bryson and their daughter Blair headed to Eden for a family holiday in April.

It was Nikki's first dive since the surgery when she finally came face to face with a massive striped marlin.

"It turned broadside to me to see what I was, because they don't see people very often," she says.

She took her shot. It wasn't until the fish was at the surface that she realised its sheer size.

Loading...

"When we finally got it on the gantry back at shore, it came in at 162.5kg. I started crying. We all just couldn't believe it," Nikki says.

It would prove to be the largest striped marlin speared in Australia, and the largest speared by a woman in the world.

It also meant Nikki was the first recorded woman in the world to achieve the famed "super slam".

They would share the fish with people back at the boat ramp, and took the rest home to share with friends over many meals.

She is happy her daughter Blair was there.

"She knows how significant it is for me," Nikki says.

"I'm sure we'll be talking about it over and over to our grandkids and they'll be sick of hearing about it," she laughs.

Nikki Watt's took top honours at the 2016 Queensland spearfishing titles. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

Diving back in

Still clear of cancer, Nikki is back spearfishing when she can.

She plans to join Bryson in Brazil at the end of the year, as he represents Australia in the Spearfishing World Championships.

Bryson is in awe of what his wife has accomplished.

"It pushes the boundaries of what's possible," he says.

"A fish like that breaks the open Australian record by 22kg. So just goes to show what is possible on spear.

Bryson said the significance of the achievement shouldn't be underestimated.

"Particularly when recovering from cancer," he says.

" It was an amazing comeback. "

Diving is a passion for Nikki Watt and Bryson Sheehy's family. (Supplied: Nikki Watt)

The experience has given Nikki a new perspective on the importance of pursuing goals without fear.

And while she is in no rush to spear a marlin again, she is keen to find the next special fish.

"There are so many things that don't seem possible, or people have been trying to do for a long time," she says.

"Anything's possible from here on."

title: Trump receives mixed reaction at US Open after security delays frustrate fans
text:
The US Open men's championship match has been delayed and thousands of seats remained empty when it finally got underway, as security checks related to President Donald Trump's attendance caused confusion and slowed entry to the iconic New York City event.

Fans waited in long lines, some for well over an hour, outside Arthur Ashe Stadium in Queens, the largest tennis venue in the world with a nearly 24,000-person capacity.

US Secret Service and other federal security officers checked bags and ushered fans through metal detectors.

Some attendees who were still outside booed as the match between rivals Carlos Alcaraz and Jannik Sinner began a little before 3pm local time.

Inside the stadium, Mr Trump was greeted by a mix of cheers and boos when he was shown on the screens.

Kevin, a Brooklyn man employed by a private equity firm, said he had waited an hour and 15 minutes and still had not reached the entrance.

The man, who declined to give his last name, blamed Mr Trump for the delay.

The security arrangements for the president delayed the start of the match. (AP Photo: Seth Wenig)

"One hundred per cent him. Very selfish. I would expect someone like that to have a little bit more grace to know that an event like this would be held up for him being here, especially in a city that hates him," he said.

A Secret Service spokesperson said in a statement: "We recognise that enhanced security for the President's visit to the US Open may have contributed to delays for attendees. We sincerely thank every fan for their patience and understanding."

Strict security measures are standard for any public event that the president attends, regardless of party affiliation or popularity.

The match start time, originally set for 2pm local, was pushed back by 30 minutes due to security checks, US Open organisers said shortly before it was set to begin.

The United States Tennis Association, which runs the event, did not immediately respond to a request for comment on the security delays.

The stadium appeared to be nearly full about an hour into the match, as Sinner and Alcaraz battled in the second set.

Mixed reaction for Trump

There was a mixed reaction to the US president. (Getty Images: Kevin Dietsch)

Mr Trump, a Republican, is a sports fan who regularly voices his opinion about sports in the same way he has sought to influence or intimidate institutions throughout US society.

He has pushed to restrict transgender women from participating in women's sports and called for the Washington Commanders football team to revert to its former name, the Redskins, a moniker that critics view as a racist portrayal of Native Americans.

Mr Trump's approval rating stood at 40 per cent in late July and mid-August, Reuters/Ipsos polls found, the lowest of his presidency.

On all policies, Mr Trump's support came overwhelmingly from Republicans, raising questions about how he would be received in New York, a Democratic stronghold.

Maribeth Lodes from New York City said her ticket cost $US350 ($530). She was in the line at 1:30pm and still had not entered an hour and a half later.

"It's ridiculous. I think it's totally unreasonable that they do this. It makes me even more infuriated, because, like, you know, we spent all of this money," she said.

Some attendees, however, were fine with Mr Trump's presence.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"He can go wherever he wants and attend a match if he wants to," said Karen Stark, a retired tennis fan, who travelled to the final from Michigan.

Resale tickets to the event ranged from hundreds of dollars to more than $20,000, according to the website SeatGeek.

The president, a regular golfer on the weekends in the Washington area or at his properties in New Jersey and Florida, has attended multiple sports events as president since returning to the White House in January.

He went to the Super Bowl in February, receiving cheers and boos from the crowd, and has attended Ultimate Fighting Championship bouts.

A television broadcast by America's ABC network showed Mr Trump stepping out of a box seat after arriving to wave to the still-sparse crowd, but it did not include crowd audio.

Cheers and boos were audible during the ESPN feed of a later Trump appearance before the start of the event.

The USTA had asked broadcasters to remove any reaction to Mr Trump, according to reports over the weekend.

A USTA spokesperson told Reuters the association regularly asked broadcasters "to refrain from showcasing off-court disruptions".

Reuters

title: Calls to review drought policy to better help struggling farmers
text:
Farmers are hoping for a total review of how drought support is being rolled out across the nation, as the country's agricultural leaders gather today for a major drought forum in South Australia.

It comes as drought-stricken farmers in southern Australia hang their hopes on a wet spring to turn their fortunes around.

Rain remains particularly scarce in SA's Riverland and Mallee, where farmer Tim Paschke received less than a third of his usual growing season rainfall.

"We're about three or four weeks away from de-stocking, and we've got enough hay and donated hay to finish off, but we're out of grain," Mr Paschke said.

"We've fed pretty much for two years straight now and we were ready for that, but it gets to a point where we just can't anymore."

Mallee farmer Tim Paschke says he will not be shaving his beard until there is a break in the drought. (ABC Rural: Kerrie Lush)

Mr Paschke hoped today's National Drought Forum would look at "some real on-the-ground help" for farmers.

"Obviously, as farmers we're really battling for cash flow," he said.

"When this harvest doesn't look like it's going to turn out — you know, obviously stock prices have been as good as they have, but the reality is that's only such a small proportion of cropping inputs.

" We need cash flow and that hopefully looks like something towards zero or low-interest loans. "

Farmers want voices heard

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese visited drought-affected South Australian farms in June, where he announced the drought forum would be moved from Victoria to SA, at the request of the National Farmers' Federation (NFF).

Anthony Albanese visited SA farms in June, where he announced the state would host the National Drought Forum. (ABC News: Lincoln Rothall)

NFF president David Johinke said today's forum was about "farmers' voices being heard" in improving Australia's drought policies.

"There's a lot to be done in the drought space; we definitely don't have the settings right underneath the current framework," Mr Johinke said.

He said farmers were calling for a raft of different drought support measures, without "any clear pathway" to how those would be activated or delivered.

"Having a total review of how we actually activate this assistance — is it via the old system of declarations that put lines on a maps? But at least people understood what the process was," Mr Johinke said.

"The new system doesn't necessarily have that transparency between state and federal, or state to state, and we want some coherence between those responsibilities to make sure everybody's doing their parts in a timely manner when agriculture and rural communities need the most support."

Hopes for spring relief

While some parts of the country received record winter rain, many southern producers remain in need of a decent spring downpour to restore the balance after months of record-low falls.

Conditions have improved significantly in Victoria, after a horror start to the year.

The Bureau of Meteorology has forecast a wet spring for eastern Australia, which will hopefully bring some relief to farmers. (ABC News: Sarah Hancock)

Widespread rain at the end of August delivered a much-needed drink for crops and pastures, but parts of north-west Victoria remain very dry, and stock water shortages persist in areas of the south-west.

Almost half of New South Wales is still classified as "in drought" or "drought affected".

In the Riverina, where people have been battling drought for up to 18 months, the paddocks are green — but producers are counting on spring rainfall to grow pastures and ensure crop yields.

Farmers cautiously optimistic

After more than a year of some of the worst drought conditions in memory, SA farmers are experiencing some cautious optimism that forecasts for a wet spring could turn things around.

Eyre Peninsula farmer Andrew Polkinghorne received above-average rainfall at his Lock property over winter, allowing him to feel optimistic about spring.

Lock farmer Andrew Polkinghorne is feeling more optimistic after above-average rain over the past three months. (ABC Rural: Brooke Neindorf)

"I think if we can get a reasonable next six weeks, then we will be quite reasonably set up," Mr Polkinghorne said.

He hoped some help could come from today's drought forum.

"I travelled overseas last year, and particularly in US and Canada, they've got multi-peril insurance schemes and I reckon it's worth another look at them," Mr Polkinghorne said.

" There's also a case for some low-interest loans to go out. This has been done in the past and it's been quite successful. "

Ungarra farmer Ben Pugsley was also feeling optimistic heading into spring after some recent rain, and hoped the drought forum would highlight how tough it was being a farmer.

Ungarra farmer Ben Pugsley says there's still a lot of work to do to finish the season off. (ABC Rural: Brooke Neindorf)

"Probably our greatest challenge at times is financial strain and land prices are going up, machinery is going up, inputs are going up, it's becoming tighter and tighter," Mr Pugsley said.

"We can have some great years and we don't have to be too far off the mark and we find ourselves fairly under a financial strain.

"So those regions that are stringing together a couple of seasons that are poor, that financial strain is getting really tight and it's so hard for them."

title: It accidentally became a skateboarding mecca. Now it's up for heritage listing
text:
Nestled among trees in Canberra's south is a historic site people travel across the world to visit.

Built in the 1980s of brick and concrete, the Erindale Brick Banks has become a popular stop on Australian tours for professional skateboarders.

"You can go around the world and talk to other skateboarders and show them photos of that spot, and they might not know what Canberra is or what Tuggeranong is, but they'll recognise that location," said Brenden 'Woody' Wood, the Canberra Skateboarding Association vice-president.

"Tony Hawk skated there in the '80s before it was a skate park."

Tony Hawk skateboarding at the Erindale Brick Banks in the 1980s. (Supplied: David Pang)

The curved brick structures were not initially built for skateboarding, but rather as part of landscaping around the Erindale college and library.

"What is left in the skate park is the remnant," Mr Wood said.

"Everything else has been renovated, but the part that was at the skate park was accidentally built so well for the purpose of skateboarding that it was turned into a purpose-built skate park later."

Fearing the iconic cultural space would be lost to development, the skateboarding community nominated the Brick Banks for listing on the ACT Heritage Register.

The Erindale Brick Banks now has provisional heritage protection. (Facebook: ACT government)

After almost 10 years of waiting, the ACT Heritage Council has granted the site provisional heritage protection, with the final decision due in November.

But the skate park is just one of many sites across the capital with a history worth preserving.

Public housing turned into private heritage

To attract workers to the capital, the government built public housing across Canberra.

The Northbourne Housing Precinct, designed by renowned architect Sydney Ancher, was built in 1962 and housed public servants and then served as public housing until the land was sold off and most of the ageing flats demolished.

Most of the old flats along Northbourne Avenue were demolished to make way for new developments. (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)

A "representative sample" of five building types of the precinct were listed on the ACT Heritage Register and as a condition of buying the block, developers had to retain and preserve the heritage, which included the buildings and the curtilage — landscaping, paths and trees.

"Our challenge was that we wanted to make them last now that they're heritage listed," said Gabe Szivek, Art Group development director.

"So we've changed all the windows with new glass, we insulated the walls, and we fire-rated. Internally, we were able to rejig the floor plan to make it how we would use our apartments today."

Gabe Szivek from Art Group in front of one of the original flats that has been incorporated into a modern development on Northbourne Avenue. (ABC News)

Working with heritage and landscape architects and other experts, the renovation maintained the building's external character while completely modernising its interior.

The project demonstrated how heritage could coexist with increasing housing density, and what was a constraint became a focal point for the development, and there are now around 148 apartments where previously there were 21.

'I just thought an error had been made'

Trees are also listed on the ACT Heritage Register, and while a heritage building cannot be knocked down, heritage trees can be.

Between 1940 and 1964, the Council for Scientific and Industrial Research's (now the CSIRO) experiment station in Downer trialled farming techniques and grew experimental crops, including opium for the war effort.

Rows of Monterey (radiata) pines and other trees were planted as windbreaks, and these trees were added to the ACT Heritage Register in 1998.

The Council for Scientific and Industrial Research's (now the CSIRO) experiment station in Downer in 1952. (Supplied: ACT Heritage Library)

When Robyn Sirr bought her sunny north-facing apartment in 2021, there were no heritage trees on site, or in sight. They had been cut down for the development.

"I had assumed that when old trees were removed, a fresh decision is made about what's appropriate now in this environment," she said.

"When we heard that Canary Island pines were going to be here … I just thought a big error had been made."

When Robyn Sirr bought her apartment in 2021, there were no Canary Island pines planted along the street. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

The government design standard says that Canary Island pines are not suitable as street trees because they drop pine cones, generate a lot of pollen and present a "medium to high flammability risk".

Ms Sirr and other concerned residents advocated to their local MLAs, who indicated it was a heritage matter.

Writing to the Heritage Council, they proposed the pines be replaced with deciduous trees to keep a tree canopy but allow winter sun and summer shade.

Canary Island pines can grow 25 metres tall. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

This was denied because the Heritage Act stipulates replacing "like for like". A compromise was made by planting the trees three metres to the north.

"These trees grow up to 25 metres tall, and that's going to cast a wall of winter shade right across the north-facing building," Ms Sirr said.

"It is possible to get win-win compromises that can work to acknowledge heritage, but find ways to do it adaptively and relevant way."

Rows of Canary Island pines were planted to replace the original Monterey Pines in 2022. (ABC News: Luke Stephenson)

The only option remaining was to apply to cancel the heritage status of the trees. A decision is expected in November.

"I really hope that we can find sensible local solutions rather than just such a black and white, siloed approach," Ms Sirr said.

Balancing the old and the new

The ACT Heritage Council is tasked with the job of assessing nominations against a set list of criteria to determine whether they should be registered, retained and protected.

"We work with the [Heritage] Minister and other parts of government to make sure we're working together," Catherine Skippington, ACT Heritage Council chair, said.

" But we still make our decisions independently. "

The council is made up of experts from a range of fields and backgrounds.

"They are smart and reasonable people. So it is a balanced decision that gets made and also open to the ideas that come in through consultation processes," Ms Skippington said.

In 2022, then-heritage minister Rebecca Vassarotti dismissed the entire council and an inquiry was held into the effectiveness and operation of heritage issues in the ACT.

Now with new members, the council is working through a significant backlog of heritage nominations, some dating back decades, prioritising the cases based on immediate threats and relevance to the community or businesses.

"I've just been [made] aware … that there are long-standing, very old nominations, which we're cleaning up," Ms Skippington said.

Moving forward, she said the council wanted to be "timely" with its assessments of nominations.

"We don't want to cost people money. We don't want property owners to be put to undue time when they're trying to get on with their lives or their businesses," she said.

"So we try and balance the time and effort and risk and the value that we're looking to protect."

Civic Centre looking north up Northbourne Avenue in1950. (Supplied: ACT Heritage Library)

Ms Skippington pointed to successful adaptive reuse examples like the Kingston shops, where heritage facades were protected while allowing modern development above.

"It's getting that balance of the old story but moving forward," she said

While some heritage sites have been protected over the years, others have been lost.

"There are times and places where it won't be possible to protect what's there. But it doesn't mean we forget it or that we can't include aspects of it in the new development," Ms Skippington said.

"Probably the best path forward is where we can combine both."

Shannon Battisson says Canberra has a fantastic legacy of brutalist architecture. (ABC News: Stuart Carnegie)

It is a sentiment echoed by Shannon Battisson, a past president of the Australian Institute of Architects.

She said protecting Canberra's heritage didn't mean the city couldn't grow or change.

"But I do think that it's really important to look at the buildings that we have around us and to really carefully decide which ones we want to keep and adapt to a modern future … and which ones we can let go and and replace with something new," she said.

"It's about looking at the spaces in between, about looking at the value of that building both in terms of the social and legacy input, but also the environmental load that it's got.

"We shouldn't be so quick to knock things down just because a little bit of thought and a little bit of extra effort has to go into retrofitting it.

"They're well worth it and they're really wonderful parts of our city and we'll regret them in the future if we simply knock everything down."

title: Tasmania's greyhound industry says it has 'strong argument' to drop ban
text:
Man On Fire claimed victory in Race 2 at Queensland's Q-Straight track last Monday night.

Leading from start to finish, the greyhound clocked the 300 metres in 16.42 seconds.

It was a race like any other, but carried the unusual name "Save Greyhound Racing In Tasmania".

Similarly named races have been run at other meetings in Queensland and New South Wales.

Last Monday's greyhound race meet in Purga, west of Brisbane, was one of a number of meets where support for Tasmanian greyhound racing was promoted. (Supplied: Racing Queensland)

It is an insight into a nationwide campaign mobilised since the Tasmanian Liberal government's decision last month to legislate a ban on greyhound racing.

Attendees and participants at interstate meets have also donned yellow caps branded with messages of support for Tasmanian greyhound racing.

Printed caps in support of Tasmania's greyhound industry have been spotted track-side. (Supplied)

A Facebook group called "Save Tasmanian Greyhound Racing" has more than 3,500 members.

Within the group, racing industry supporters share their anger and discuss ways to get their message out, including by emailing current and former Tasmanian MPs.

There is even a song performed with the help of AI.

Race 2 at Queensland's Q-Track last Monday was named "Save Greyhound Racing in Tasmania". (Supplied: Racing Queensland)

Industry to fight 'unjust process'

The move has fuelled fears other states may follow suit.

Recently appointed head of Greyhounds Tasmania, Luke Gatehouse, has aired his grievance about the industry's demise.

"We came together last week at our national greyhound conference … All the states reaffirmed their commitment to supporting Tasmania through what is really an unjust process that's taken place," he said.

Mr Gatehouse is the former head of the Brisbane Greyhound Racing Club, a position he held for 18 years.

He has been engaged by the Tasmanian industry as it attempts to overturn plans for the ban.

"We'll be doing our best to get the information out to people," he said.

"That's what a democracy is about, making fair-minded decisions, not political convenience."

Greyhounds a 'scapegoat' in political tussle, trainer says Photo shows Woman poses for photo, leaning against a black fence at a racecourse The announcement of funding being ended for Tasmania's greyhound racing industry has left the people who work in it "filthy, angry", a trainer says — with special mention made of the Liberal premier.

The minority Rockliff government's announcement in August about the greyhound racing ban came as both major parties were attempting to woo a mostly progressive crossbench ahead of a no-confidence vote in the parliament.

During two weeks of negotiation with the crossbench, Mr Rockliff promised to phase out greyhound racing in 2029, cancel plans to release more native forests for logging, and put a moratorium on the expansion of salmon farming.

For the Liberals, it was a pitch to stay in power, following a snap state election where neither side claimed a majority.

But it has left the greyhound industry feeling betrayed.

"If you're going to shut down one industry based on a whim, what is next? That's the question for good, fair-thinking Tasmanians," Mr Gatehouse said.

Premier says closure assured

On Sunday, Premier Jeremy Rockliff said he was aware of mainland lobbyists' attempts to fight his plans, and said he was not surprised.

"They will fail. Greyhound racing will end in 2029," he said

He said the industry's focus should be on a smooth and measured transition.

"I know that local greyhound racing participants were extremely disappointed in the decision we've made, but I'm comfortable with the decision because it's the right one."

Jeremy Rockliff made the commitment as he worked to shore up support for his leadership. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Tasmania's racing integrity commissioner Sean Carroll has announced a transition group to "ensure all appropriate support is provided" to participants.

In response, Greyhounds Tasmania penned its own open letter, calling the group "premature and inappropriate".

"The announcement of a phase out is not a settled outcome. It is a contested policy that we are actively working to overturn," it says.

Asked whether the industry needed to be involved in the group to ensure participants received the best possible outcome, Mr Gatehouse said they would have a voice "in making sure that legislation is not passed".

The Tasmanian government says greyhound racing in the state will end in 2029. (ABC News: Scout Wallen)

'Majority of Tasmanians' support the ban, detractors say

Coalition for Protection of Greyhounds president Amy MacMahon said interstate greyhound industry insiders were bound to involve themselves in the Tasmanian cause because "they know that the writing is on the wall".

"I'm not surprised that the greyhound industry and other states are starting to mobilise to push back," she said, arguing it was also an attempt to "shore up support" in their own states.

RSPCA reacts to wind up of Tasmanian greyhound racing Photo shows Andrea Dawkins with greyhound As the RSPCA celebrates the Tasmanian government's decision to end greyhound racing by 2029, one industry stalwart says he is "devastated" by the move.

The sport has been banned in the ACT since 2018.

Internationally, greyhound racing remains active in only one US state, while a New Zealand ban will be in place from July next year.

But a 2016 push to end the sport in New South Wales was ill fated, and later cast aside after industry backlash.

Ms MacMahon expects the industry to use similar tactics as it did in NSW.

"There was a concerted campaign of misinformation from the industry, from the conservative media, in that case from NSW Labor as well, who were spreading misinformation about the economic impacts and misinformation about the levels of animal abuse," she said.

"The difference in this case is that we know very clearly that the majority of Tasmanians support the ban on greyhound racing. That is irrefutable."

Recent polling by EMRS found 74 per cent of Tasmanians backed the government's decision to phase out greyhound racing.

The Q-Track west of Brisbane is Queensland's home of greyhound racing.

Ms MacMahon also criticised the role of Mr Gatehouse in the campaign, citing his involvement in the development of Queensland's new Q-Track.

There has been a string of animal deaths related to injuries at the track since it opened in March.

"The Tasmanian industry has gotten on board a lobbyist with a track record in setting up tracks causing huge amounts of death and animal abuse," she said.

Mr Gatehouse has hit back, saying he has continually been involved in improving animal welfare standards during his time in the sport.

"The thing about making sure that we're part of an acceptable code of racing within the community is to continually evolve, and we will do that," he said.

Participants 'want to do our thing'

Hobart-based Greyhound breeder and owner Greg Fahey is among those feeling bolstered by the interstate interest.

He said the industry would not give up without a fight.

"In 2029, all the dog people that are here now will still be here. I'm not sure how many that are in the current government — or on any side of the politics — are still going to be there," he said.

" We say a week is a long time in politics … four years is a millennium. "

Tasmanian greyhound racing participants say they want to "do our thing". (TasRacing)

Mr Fahey has a long history with the sport, having founded the Tasmanian greyhound hall of fame.

Along with his brother Gary, he owned one of Tasmania's most successful dogs, Raider's Guide, which was euthanased following a racing injury in July.

"We don't try to convince everyone to love greyhound racing; we just want to do our thing and let other people do their thing," he said.

He was confident industry participants would see the loss of the sport as like the "death of a friend".

He said the overturning of the ban in New South Wales proved the industry could save itself when aided by other politicians or media figures.

"We've got a very strong argument, and the rest of Australian greyhound racing is firmly behind us," he said.

title: Live: ASX slips after Wall St falls on weak US jobs figures
text:
Supermarket giant Woolworths expects the cost of repaying underpaid employees could top $500 million.

On Friday, the Federal Court handed down a judgement on the historical underpayments of salaried employees at the two major supermarkets, which Woolies described "as lengthy and complex", noting it "does not determine all issues in the proceedings", while Coles agreed it was "complex".

A further hearing on the matter is listed for late October to determine the outcome for nearly 30,000 affected employees.

"It is too early to consider any appeal on any aspects of the decision," Woolworths said in a statement this morning.

Based on its preliminary review of the court's reasons, the company expects potential one-off costs related to further remediation of $180-$330 million after tax, with interest, super and payroll tax potentially adding another $140-$200 million.

Coles, meanwhile, "cautions the market from relying on speculative estimates", in response to media reports of the potential hit to the supermarket.

"Coles' preliminary estimate is that further remediation of between $150m and $250m may be required to reflect the findings of the court, including interest and on-costs," it said on Monday.

On Friday, Justice Nye Perram found the supermarket chains did not comply with their obligation to keep accurate employment records.

Woolworths said the decision "will require significant and widespread changes to accepted retail practice for Woolworths Group and Australian businesses, large and small".

In an article on the judgement, lawyers at Kings & Wood Mallesons said "the decision will have wide-ranging implications across the businesses community and warrants prompt and decisive consideration by employers who rely" on the same previsions used by Coles and Woolies.

title: Vine misses out on Vuelta hat-trick but extends polka dots lead
text:
